greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array M(k,g), read by antidiagonals, of the Moore lower bound on the order of a (k,g)-cage.
comment: The base k-1 reading of the base 10 string of A094626(g).

Exoo and Jajcay Theorem 1: M(k,g) <= A054760(k,g) with equality if and only if: k = 2 and g >= 3; g = 3 and k >= 2; g = 4 and k >= 2; g = 5 and k = 2, 3, 7 or possibly 57; or g = 6, 8, or 12, and there exists a symmetric generalized n-gon of order k - 1.
reference: E. Bannai and T. Ito, On finite Moore graphs, J. Fac. Sci. Tokyo, Sect. 1A, 20 (1973) 191-208.
R. M. Damerell, On Moore graphs, Proc. Cambridge Phil. Soc. 74 (1973) 227-236.
link: Jason Kimberley, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20100 (k+g = 5..204)
Jason Kimberley, Table of n, k+g, k, g, M(k,g)=a(n) for k+g = 5..204 (n = 1..20100)
G. Exoo and R. Jajcay, Dynamic cage survey, Electr. J. Combin. (2008, 2011).
formula: M(k,2i) = 2 sum_{j=0}^{i-1}(k-1)^j =  string "2"^i read in base k-1.
M(k,2i+1) = (k-1)^i +  2 sum_{j=0}^{i-1}(k-1)^j = string "1"*"2"^i read in base k-1.
example: This is the table formed from the antidiagonals for k+g = 5..20:
mathematica: Table[Function[g, FromDigits[#, k - 1] &@ IntegerDigits@ SeriesCoefficient[x (1 + x)/((1 - x) (1 - 10 x^2)), {x, 0, g}]][n - k + 3], {n, 2, 12}, {k, n, 2, -1}] // Flatten (* _Michael De Vlieger_, May 15 2017 *)
xref: Cf. A054760 (the actual order of a (k,g)-cage).
results.author: _Jason Kimberley_, Oct 27 2011
